title: Chinese Government donates 600 sewing machines to the Fiji's Ministry of Women
description: On September 9, 2014, China donated 600 sewing machines to Fiji's Ministry of Women, Social Welfare and Poverty Alleviation. The 600 sewing machines are worth $64,000 and will be distributed among women in rural areas of Fiji. Huang Yong, Chinese Ambassador to Fiji, and Dr. Jiko Luveni, Fiji's Minister of Women, Social Welfare, and Poverty Alleviation, signed the donation document at the handover ceremony. According to Ambassador Huang, the sewing machines are expected to help hundreds of women achieve self-worth through creative work, and benefit hundreds of families and thousands of people in Fiji. Dr. Jiko Luveni said that the 600 sewing machines will be provided to women groups particularly those who have lodged their requests with the ministry and that the idea is for all the villages in Fiji to have two sewing machines each.  Previous donations of sewing machines were made in 2010 and 2011 (See Project #39318 and #39321).
combined_text:
# Sector
GOVERNMENT AND CIVIL SOCIETY

# Title
Chinese Government donates 600 sewing machines to the Fiji's Ministry of Women

# Description
On September 9, 2014, China donated 600 sewing machines to Fiji's Ministry of Women, Social Welfare and Poverty Alleviation. The 600 sewing machines are worth $64,000 and will be distributed among women in rural areas of Fiji. Huang Yong, Chinese Ambassador to Fiji, and Dr. Jiko Luveni, Fiji's Minister of Women, Social Welfare, and Poverty Alleviation, signed the donation document at the handover ceremony. According to Ambassador Huang, the sewing machines are expected to help hundreds of women achieve self-worth through creative work, and benefit hundreds of families and thousands of people in Fiji. Dr. Jiko Luveni said that the 600 sewing machines will be provided to women groups particularly those who have lodged their requests with the ministry and that the idea is for all the villages in Fiji to have two sewing machines each.  Previous donations of sewing machines were made in 2010 and 2011 (See Project #39318 and #39321).
justification: Project is a social development initiative with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Donation of sewing machines to support women's empowerment and poverty alleviation

title: Chinese Government provides leadership training for Fijian civil servants in 2014
description: Fiji has been sending members of its civil service to China’s Executive Leadership Academy of Pudong (CELAP), China's premier executive leadership training academy in Shanghai, China, to undergo short-term training. This is at the request of the Fijian Government. In 2013, it requested training for 300 officials. This request was granted. Fijian officials will be sent over in batches of 25 for the next five years.   On November 18, 2014, the Chinese Government invited 19 Fijian government officials to take part in leadership training in China. This project has been completed.   Over the course of the next two years, the Fiji Public Service Commission is looking at sending another 250 senior officials for leadership training in China and to learn firsthand the skills of strategic thinking, planning and coordination, project implementation, and effective public service delivery. Previously, on September 13, 2013, the Chinese Government invited 20 Fijian government officials to take part in leadership training in China. The second round of training for 25 officials began on November 6, 2013. As of January 22, 2014, 109 top and senior-level civil servants were trained (see project #39406).
combined_text:
# Sector
GOVERNMENT AND CIVIL SOCIETY

# Title

# Description
Fiji has been sending members of its civil service to China’s Executive Leadership Academy of Pudong (CELAP), China's premier executive leadership training academy in Shanghai, China, to undergo short-term training. This is at the request of the Fijian Government. In 2013, it requested training for 300 officials. This request was granted. Fijian officials will be sent over in batches of 25 for the next five years.   On November 18, 2014, the Chinese Government invited 19 Fijian government officials to take part in leadership training in China. This project has been completed.   Over the course of the next two years, the Fiji Public Service Commission is looking at sending another 250 senior officials for leadership training in China and to learn firsthand the skills of strategic thinking, planning and coordination, project implementation, and effective public service delivery. Previously, on September 13, 2013, the Chinese Government invited 20 Fijian government officials to take part in leadership training in China. The second round of training for 25 officials began on November 6, 2013. As of January 22, 2014, 109 top and senior-level civil servants were trained (see project #39406).
justification: Project focuses on leadership training for civil servants, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Leadership training for Fijian civil servants, focus on strategic thinking and public service delivery

title: Chinese Government grants USD 50,000 to Fiji to address dengue fever outbreak
description: On March 4, 2014, the Chinese Government donated USD 50,000 to Fiji's Ministry of Health, assisting the South Pacific island country in its fight against the dengue fever outbreak that has claimed seven lives. Yang Zhaohui, the political counselor of the Chinese Embassy in Fiji, signed the donation agreement with Dr. Eloni Tora, permanent secretary of Fiji's Ministry of Health. The donation has been completed.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Chinese Government grants USD 50,000 to Fiji to address dengue fever outbreak

# Description
On March 4, 2014, the Chinese Government donated USD 50,000 to Fiji's Ministry of Health, assisting the South Pacific island country in its fight against the dengue fever outbreak that has claimed seven lives. Yang Zhaohui, the political counselor of the Chinese Embassy in Fiji, signed the donation agreement with Dr. Eloni Tora, permanent secretary of Fiji's Ministry of Health. The donation has been completed.
justification: Project is a health-related donation with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: USD 50,000 grant to address dengue fever outbreak, health sector focus

title: Chinese Government grants FJD 1,449,770 to assist Fiji in 2014 general elections
description: On June 6, 2014, China signed an agreement committing a grant of FJD 1.42 million (around USD 800,000) to Fiji for the 2014 election. The agreement was signed by Huang Yong, Chinese ambassador to Fiji and Aiyaz Sayed-Khaiyum, Fiji's acting prime minister, attorney- general, and minister responsible for elections. Chinese Ambassador Huang Yong said, "the Chinese Government is willing to provide necessary assistance for the election."  A total of FJD 1,449,770 was contributed to a grant fund set up for the 2014 election.  This grant is separate from the police assistance given by China which included equipment for the elections (see Project #64719).
combined_text:

justification: Project is focused on supporting democratic processes through election funding, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Grant for 2014 general elections, support for democratic processes

title: Chinese Government funds establishment of Chinese Cultural Center
description: In November 2014, an MoU was signed between the Chinese Foreign Affairs Minister, Wang Yi, and Fiji's Minister of Education, Heritage and Arts, Mahendra Reddy, for the construction of a Chinese cultural center in the capital city of Suva. The center would consist of a large exhibition hall, four staff offices, and a Chinese cooking display room. It would also include three classrooms for training, a library, plus an electronic reading room. The center was jointly inaugurated by senior Chinese and Fijian officials on December 15, 2015. The China Cultural Center in Fiji will present cultural events, provide Chinese language and cultural courses and information service, and serve as a platform for intellectual dialogues, said Deng Xianfu, director of the center.
combined_text:
# Sector
OTHER SOCIAL INFRASTRUCTURE AND SERVICES

# Title
Chinese Government funds establishment of Chinese Cultural Center

# Description
In November 2014, an MoU was signed between the Chinese Foreign Affairs Minister, Wang Yi, and Fiji's Minister of Education, Heritage and Arts, Mahendra Reddy, for the construction of a Chinese cultural center in the capital city of Suva. The center would consist of a large exhibition hall, four staff offices, and a Chinese cooking display room. It would also include three classrooms for training, a library, plus an electronic reading room. The center was jointly inaugurated by senior Chinese and Fijian officials on December 15, 2015. The China Cultural Center in Fiji will present cultural events, provide Chinese language and cultural courses and information service, and serve as a platform for intellectual dialogues, said Deng Xianfu, director of the center.
justification: Project focuses on cultural exchange and education without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Cultural center with exhibition hall, classrooms, library, and reading room for cultural exchange and education

title: Chinese Government provides grant funding for Vunidawa Sports Complex Construction Project (Linked to Project ID#68688)
description: On November 22, 2014, the Chinese Government and the Government of Fiji signed an MOU regarding a grant for the Vunidawa Sports Complex Construction Project. In an official letter of engagement, China's Minister of Commerce, Gao Hucheng, indicated that the Chinese Government would be responsible for the design of the project, provision of needed construction machinery, equipment and materials along with the dispatching of the necessary number of engineers and technicians to Fiji to carry out the construction. Then, in the 2015 Budget Address, Fiji’s Minister of Finance, Aiyaz Sayed-Khaiyum, indicated that the Chinese Government had confirmed its commitment to fund the Vunidawa Sports Complex, although the actual cost of the project was not specified.   The purpose of the project is to construct a sporting complex — with a maximum capacity of 4,500 seats with a total construction area of 1,475 square meters — in the town of Vunidawa within Naitasiri Province. China Northeast Architectural Design and Research Institute Co. Ltd. is the contractor responsible for project design and China Gezhouba Group Company Ltd. is the contractor responsible for project implementation.   In late March 2015, Chinese surveyors and designers began site evaluations, and the China Northeast Architectural Design and Research Institute Co. Ltd. began initial evaluation, planning and work at the proposed project site. However, according to the Consolidated Review Report on the Office of the Prime Minister Annual Report 2013 and the Office of the Prime Minister Annual Report 2014 (as well as the May 2019 Review of the 2015 Budget Report), the initially proposed project site was costly (because of its position on a hill side) and prone to flooding. Consequently, the Chinese technical team declined the project proposal.   A new project site was identified and the Government of Fiji allocated funding for land acquisition in FY2017. An article from January 2018 indicates that construction of the Vunidawa Sports Complex at the new site was underway. However, no further implementation details could be identified.
staff_comments: This project is also known as the Rural Sports Complex in Vunidawa Project.According to the Consolidated Review Report on the Office of the Prime Minister Annual Report 2013 and the Office of the Prime Minister Annual Report 2014, the Chinese Government agreed to begin discussions with the Government of Fiji about the construction of sporting complexes in Korovou and Seaqaqa once the implementation of the Vunidawa Sports Complex Construction Project had begun. This issue merits further investigation.
combined_text:
# Sector
OTHER SOCIAL INFRASTRUCTURE AND SERVICES

# Title
Chinese Government provides grant funding for Vunidawa Sports Complex Construction Project (Linked to Project ID#68688)

# Description
On November 22, 2014, the Chinese Government and the Government of Fiji signed an MOU regarding a grant for the Vunidawa Sports Complex Construction Project. In an official letter of engagement, China's Minister of Commerce, Gao Hucheng, indicated that the Chinese Government would be responsible for the design of the project, provision of needed construction machinery, equipment and materials along with the dispatching of the necessary number of engineers and technicians to Fiji to carry out the construction. Then, in the 2015 Budget Address, Fiji’s Minister of Finance, Aiyaz Sayed-Khaiyum, indicated that the Chinese Government had confirmed its commitment to fund the Vunidawa Sports Complex, although the actual cost of the project was not specified.   The purpose of the project is to construct a sporting complex — with a maximum capacity of 4,500 seats with a total construction area of 1,475 square meters — in the town of Vunidawa within Naitasiri Province. China Northeast Architectural Design and Research Institute Co. Ltd. is the contractor responsible for project design and China Gezhouba Group Company Ltd. is the contractor responsible for project implementation.   In late March 2015, Chinese surveyors and designers began site evaluations, and the China Northeast Architectural Design and Research Institute Co. Ltd. began initial evaluation, planning and work at the proposed project site. However, according to the Consolidated Review Report on the Office of the Prime Minister Annual Report 2013 and the Office of the Prime Minister Annual Report 2014 (as well as the May 2019 Review of the 2015 Budget Report), the initially proposed project site was costly (because of its position on a hill side) and prone to flooding. Consequently, the Chinese technical team declined the project proposal.   A new project site was identified and the Government of Fiji allocated funding for land acquisition in FY2017. An article from January 2018 indicates that construction of the Vunidawa Sports Complex at the new site was underway. However, no further implementation details could be identified.
justification: Project is focused on social infrastructure development with no direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Construction of sports complex, social infrastructure focus, no energy or environmental components mentioned

title: Chinese Government provides RMB 8.2 million grant for Phase 1 of Juncao Mushroom Technical Cooperation Project (Linked to Project ID#65032)
description: In 2014, the Chinese Government provided an RMB 8.2 million (FJD 14 million) grant to the Government of Fiji for Phase 1 of the Juncao Mushroom Technological Cooperation Project. The purpose of this project is to train Fijian farmers in the Juncao technique for cultivating mushrooms. Chinese Professor Lin Zhanxi perfected the Juncao technique for growing mushrooms from grass in the 1980s and has shared his technology with developing countries with the help of the Chinese Government. The Fijian Ministry of Agriculture, working with the Fujian Agriculture & Forestry University (FAFU), and the China National Engineering Research Center of JUNCAO Technology collaborated through this project to increase the supply and domestic sale of mushrooms in Fiji.   Phase 1 commenced in September 2014. It involved the construction of a 3,100 square meter demonstration farm (by Hebei Construction Group) — at the Legalega Research Station on the outskirts of the city of Nadi — with processing workshops, laboratories, training classrooms, trainee dormitories, and a 20,000 square meter nursery garden. The purpose of the demonstration farm (known as the Juncao Technology Demonstration Center) was to grow mushrooms and teach farmers how to cultivate them successfully so they could start their own small businesses. Phase 1 also involved involved testing the viability of the Juncao Technology (using dried and chopped grasses to grow mushrooms), and educating officials from the Ministry of Agriculture as well as local farmers about this technology. Because Juncao is a simple technology (requiring no soil and only a small area of space) and the mushrooms grow relatively quickly, demand for training was high. At least 7 trainings were held, and the project successfully commercialized Juncao mushrooms on Fiji’s domestic market. To help local farmers start mushroom businesses, the Chinese Government donated implements, machines, and other planting materials to the Fiji Ministry of Agriculture in late September 2016 (marking the end of Phase 1).    The first harvest in late 2014 yielded approximately 200 kilograms. A hectare produces around 500 tonnes of fresh grass, which can produce 150 tonnes of fresh mushroom. Fiji is now expected to produce 30,000 kilograms of mushrooms annually, which will help diversify its exports and alleviate rural poverty. As of late January 2015, the project has helped Fiji with producing about 1 million bags of edible and medicinal mushrooms, and technical personnel training of more than 100 people.
staff_comments: This project is also known as the Mushroom Project, the First Phase of the Juncao Technological Demonstration Program, and the First Phase of the Juncao Mushroom Technology Demonstration Center Project. The Chinese project title is 中国援助斐济菌草技术合作项目.Phase 2 of the project, which the Chinese Government also financed, supported additional trainings and the creation of a production line for mushrooms at the demonstration site – from seedlings to packaging and storage – that produces an annual output of 300 tones of fresh mushrooms (as captured in Project ID#65032). As the project continues, it hopes to provide Fijian’s with new livelihood options, as well as going some way to address the nation’s food import dependency.”
combined_text:
# Sector
AGRICULTURE, FORESTRY, FISHING

# Title
Chinese Government provides RMB 8.2 million grant for Phase 1 of Juncao Mushroom Technical Cooperation Project (Linked to Project ID#65032)

# Description
In 2014, the Chinese Government provided an RMB 8.2 million (FJD 14 million) grant to the Government of Fiji for Phase 1 of the Juncao Mushroom Technological Cooperation Project. The purpose of this project is to train Fijian farmers in the Juncao technique for cultivating mushrooms. Chinese Professor Lin Zhanxi perfected the Juncao technique for growing mushrooms from grass in the 1980s and has shared his technology with developing countries with the help of the Chinese Government. The Fijian Ministry of Agriculture, working with the Fujian Agriculture & Forestry University (FAFU), and the China National Engineering Research Center of JUNCAO Technology collaborated through this project to increase the supply and domestic sale of mushrooms in Fiji.   Phase 1 commenced in September 2014. It involved the construction of a 3,100 square meter demonstration farm (by Hebei Construction Group) — at the Legalega Research Station on the outskirts of the city of Nadi — with processing workshops, laboratories, training classrooms, trainee dormitories, and a 20,000 square meter nursery garden. The purpose of the demonstration farm (known as the Juncao Technology Demonstration Center) was to grow mushrooms and teach farmers how to cultivate them successfully so they could start their own small businesses. Phase 1 also involved involved testing the viability of the Juncao Technology (using dried and chopped grasses to grow mushrooms), and educating officials from the Ministry of Agriculture as well as local farmers about this technology. Because Juncao is a simple technology (requiring no soil and only a small area of space) and the mushrooms grow relatively quickly, demand for training was high. At least 7 trainings were held, and the project successfully commercialized Juncao mushrooms on Fiji’s domestic market. To help local farmers start mushroom businesses, the Chinese Government donated implements, machines, and other planting materials to the Fiji Ministry of Agriculture in late September 2016 (marking the end of Phase 1).    The first harvest in late 2014 yielded approximately 200 kilograms. A hectare produces around 500 tonnes of fresh grass, which can produce 150 tonnes of fresh mushroom. Fiji is now expected to produce 30,000 kilograms of mushrooms annually, which will help diversify its exports and alleviate rural poverty. As of late January 2015, the project has helped Fiji with producing about 1 million bags of edible and medicinal mushrooms, and technical personnel training of more than 100 people.
justification: Project focuses on agricultural training and rural development without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Juncao mushroom cultivation training, demonstration farm construction, focus on rural poverty alleviation and agricultural diversification

title: Chinese Embassy donates 4,547 books on China to Fijian school library
description: On July 1, 2014, the Chinese Embassy donated 4,547 books about China to Yat-Sen Primary School library in Suva, Fiji. The donated books covered topics such as Chinese politics, society, economy, culture, education, history, and art. It is expected that these books can improve students' understanding of Chinese society and Chinese language skills.
combined_text:
# Sector
EDUCATION

# Title
Chinese Embassy donates 4,547 books on China to Fijian school library

# Description
On July 1, 2014, the Chinese Embassy donated 4,547 books about China to Yat-Sen Primary School library in Suva, Fiji. The donated books covered topics such as Chinese politics, society, economy, culture, education, history, and art. It is expected that these books can improve students' understanding of Chinese society and Chinese language skills.
justification: Project is focused on educational materials donation without direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Book donation to school library, focus on cultural and educational exchange

title: Overseas Chinese Affairs Office provides grant for Fiji-China Friendship Pavilion Construction Project
description: On January 28, 2017, the Fiji-China Friendship Pavilion was officially completed. Construction was financed by a grant from the Overseas Chinese Affairs Office. The monetary value of this grant is unknown. It is unclear when construction began. The donation was part of a celebration marking the 160th anniversary of the arrival of Chinese Fijians.   Fiji’s Prime Minister Bainimarama attended the opening ceremony. China’s Ambassador to Fiji Zhang Ping spoke at the ceremony and noted that “[b]eing a public facility situated in the center of the Suva downtown area, the pavilion is for use by the general public. It will not only provide a place for pedestrians to sit and relax, it will also become a city landmark and new tourist attraction to many people particularly tourist from China.”   The pavilion was constructed in the traditional Chinese style that can be found in temples, parks and gardens all throughout China. It was first constructed in China before being re-assembled along the Terry Walk in the city of Suva.  Its latitude and longitude coordinates are -18.138410, 178.426159.
combined_text:

title: Chinese Government donates musical instruments worth FJD 19,000 to Fiji Ministry of Education, Heritage, Culture and Art
description: On September 12, 2014, the Chinese Government donated musical equipment to the Fiji Ministry of Education, Heritage, Culture and Art, specifically red electric guitars. The donated instruments also included television sets, laptops, and multimedia projectors worth FJD 19,000. It is expected that these instruments will help to promote the cultural life of the Fiji people.
